summary: This exploratory study addresses the gap in research concerning the ability of older adults with Parkinson's disease (PD) to rise from the floor, despite significant attention to fall prevention. It investigates the relationship between the ability to rise from the floor and various physical performance tests. The study involved twenty community-dwelling older adults with a mean age of 74.8 years, who completed a standardized floor rise test. Results indicated that the average time to rise from the floor was 14.9 seconds, with 70% of participants using a quadruped strategy to stand. Additionally, the time taken to rise was significantly correlated with other physical performance measures. The findings emphasize the importance of assessing floor rise ability in clinical settings to prevent adverse outcomes from falls and to improve fall recovery techniques.
